fields.summary: [Rust] cast kernel does not support casting from Int64

status.description: The issue is considered finished, the resolution is correct. Issues which are not closed can be reopened.
status.name: Closed

status.description: A resolution has been taken, and it is awaiting verification by reporter. From here issues are either reopened, or are closed.

worklogs.comment:
andygrove commented on pull request #4054: ARROW-5039: [Rust] [DataFusion] Re-implement CAST support
URL: https://github.com/apache/arrow/pull/4054
 
 
   This PR achieves a few things:
   
   - Removes some PoC code and replaces it with generic code for evaluating CAST expressions
   - Adds support for casting from UInt64 in arrow compute module (looks like this was just missed)
   - Improves error messages and rustdocs
   - Adds a bounds check to avoid a panic if a column index is incorrect
 
----------------------------------------------------------------

 ##########
 File path: rust/arrow/src/compute/kernels/cast.rs

 @@ -283,6 +283,16 @@ pub fn cast(array: &ArrayRef, to_type: &DataType) -> Result<ArrayRef> {
         (Int32, Float32) => cast_numeric_arrays::<Int32Type, Float32Type>(array),

         (Int32, Float64) => cast_numeric_arrays::<Int32Type, Float64Type>(array),
 
+        (Int64, UInt8) => cast_numeric_arrays::<Int64Type, UInt8Type>(array),
 
 Review comment:
   @sunchao I've reverted the change to the arrow cast kernel and filed https://issues.apache.org/jira/browse/ARROW-5065.
   
   This reduces the scope of this PR to just the datafusion change to replace the hacky POC code with generic code for casting between any type.

URL: https://github.com/apache/arrow/pull/4054#discussion_r270233147

 @@ -283,6 +283,16 @@ pub fn cast(array: &ArrayRef, to_type: &DataType) -> Result<ArrayRef> {

andygrove commented on pull request #4054: ARROW-5039: [Rust] [DataFusion] Re-implement CAST support
URL: https://github.com/apache/arrow/pull/4054#discussion_r270242871
 
 

 ##########
 File path: rust/arrow/src/compute/kernels/cast.rs
 ##########
 @@ -283,6 +283,16 @@ pub fn cast(array: &ArrayRef, to_type: &DataType) -> Result<ArrayRef> {
         (Int32, Float32) => cast_numeric_arrays::<Int32Type, Float32Type>(array),
         (Int32, Float64) => cast_numeric_arrays::<Int32Type, Float64Type>(array),
 
+        (Int64, UInt8) => cast_numeric_arrays::<Int64Type, UInt8Type>(array),
 
 Review comment:
   OK @nevi-me @sunchao I have added unit tests for casting from `int64` to all other numeric types. I am only testing for valid conversions.
   
   I was surprised to discover that casts resulting in overflow are actually non deterministic and produce seemingly random results.
 
----------------------------------------------------------------
This is an automated message from the Apache Git Service.
To respond to the message, please log on to GitHub and use the
URL above to go to the specific comment.
 
For queries about this service, please contact Infrastructure at:
users@infra.apache.org

nevi-me commented on pull request #4054: ARROW-5039: [Rust] [DataFusion] Re-implement CAST support
URL: https://github.com/apache/arrow/pull/4054#discussion_r270286946
 
 

 ##########
 File path: rust/arrow/src/compute/kernels/cast.rs
 ##########
 @@ -283,6 +283,16 @@ pub fn cast(array: &ArrayRef, to_type: &DataType) -> Result<ArrayRef> {
         (Int32, Float32) => cast_numeric_arrays::<Int32Type, Float32Type>(array),
         (Int32, Float64) => cast_numeric_arrays::<Int32Type, Float64Type>(array),
 
+        (Int64, UInt8) => cast_numeric_arrays::<Int64Type, UInt8Type>(array),
 
 Review comment:
   Hi @andygrove, the non-deterministic random results are because we never write the 'invalid' array into memory, but rather append a null.
   With say `-1i8 as u8`, one would expect an underflow to `255u8`, but because we use `num::NumCast` for casting, I suspect it uses a convenience check to mark all negative casts to unsigned as invalid.
   
   The relevant code's https://github.com/apache/arrow/blob/master/rust/arrow/src/compute/kernels/cast.rs#L346
 
----------------------------------------------------------------
This is an automated message from the Apache Git Service.
To respond to the message, please log on to GitHub and use the
URL above to go to the specific comment.

users@infra.apache.org

nevi-me commented on pull request #4054: ARROW-5039: [Rust] [DataFusion] Re-implement CAST support
URL: https://github.com/apache/arrow/pull/4054#discussion_r270286946
 
 

 ##########
 File path: rust/arrow/src/compute/kernels/cast.rs
 ##########
 @@ -283,6 +283,16 @@ pub fn cast(array: &ArrayRef, to_type: &DataType) -> Result<ArrayRef> {
         (Int32, Float32) => cast_numeric_arrays::<Int32Type, Float32Type>(array),
         (Int32, Float64) => cast_numeric_arrays::<Int32Type, Float64Type>(array),
 
+        (Int64, UInt8) => cast_numeric_arrays::<Int64Type, UInt8Type>(array),
 
 Review comment:
   Hi @andygrove, the non-deterministic random results are because we never write the 'invalid' element into the array, but rather append a null.
   With say `-1i8 as u8`, one would expect an underflow to `255u8`, but because we use `num::NumCast` for casting, I suspect it uses a convenience check to mark all negative casts to unsigned as invalid.
   
   The relevant code's https://github.com/apache/arrow/blob/master/rust/arrow/src/compute/kernels/cast.rs#L346
 
----------------------------------------------------------------

nevi-me commented on pull request #4054: ARROW-5039: [Rust] [DataFusion] Re-implement CAST support
URL: https://github.com/apache/arrow/pull/4054#discussion_r270288680
 
 

 ##########
 File path: rust/arrow/src/compute/kernels/cast.rs
 ##########
 @@ -283,6 +283,16 @@ pub fn cast(array: &ArrayRef, to_type: &DataType) -> Result<ArrayRef> {
         (Int32, Float32) => cast_numeric_arrays::<Int32Type, Float32Type>(array),
         (Int32, Float64) => cast_numeric_arrays::<Int32Type, Float64Type>(array),
 
+        (Int64, UInt8) => cast_numeric_arrays::<Int64Type, UInt8Type>(array),
 
 Review comment:
   Just checked, it returns `None` if 0 > signed value. https://github.com/rust-num/num-traits/blob/master/src/cast.rs#L130
   
   Maybe we can revisit this as @sunchao suggested. I'll have a look at the CPP implementation. I used `num-traits::cast` because I spent a while trying to get cast right, as there were some instances where primitive `as` casts aren't supported by rustc.
 
----------------------------------------------------------------
